metadata.titleEn: Glacier coverage data on the Tibetan Plateau in 2001 (TPG2001, Version1.0)
metadata.description: The Tibetan Plateau Glacial Data –TPG2001 is a glacial coverage data on the Tibetan Plateau in around 2000 from 150 scenes of Landsat7 TM/ETM+ images by 30 m spatial resolution. The selected Landsat7 TM/ETM+ images were within the period between 1999 and 2002, including 61 scenes (41%) in 2001 and 47 scenes (31%) in 2000. Among all the images, 71% was taken in winter. The most frequent year in this period was defined as the reference year for the mosaic image: i.e. 2001. Glacier outlines were digitized on-screen manually from the 2001 image mosaic, relying on false-colour image composites (RGB by bands 543), which allowed us to distinguish ice/snow from cloud. Debris-free ice was distinguished from the debris and debris-covered ice by its higher reflectance. Debris-covered ice was not delineated in this data. The delineated glacier outlines were compared with band-ratio (e.g. TM3/TM5) results, and validated by overlapping them onto Google Earth imagery, SRTM DEM, topographic maps and corresponding satellite images. Topographic maps from the 1970s and all available satellite images (including Google EarthTM imagery) were used as base reference data. For areas with mountain shadows and snow cover, they were verified by different methods using data from different seasons. For glaciers in deep shadow, Google EarthTM imagery from different dates was used as the reference for manual delineation. Steep slopes or headwalls were also excluded in the TPG2001. Areas that appeared in any of these sources to have the characteristics of exposed ground/basement/bed rock were manually delineated as non-glacier, and were also cross-checked with CGI-1 and CGI-2. Steep hanging glaciers were included in TPG2001 if they were identifiable on images in all three epochs (i.e. TPG1976, TPG2001, and TPG2013). The accuracy of manual digitization was controlled within one half-pixel. All glacier areas were calculated on the WGS84 spheroid in an Albers equal-area map projection centred at (95°E, 30°N) with standard parallels at 15°N and 65°N. Our results showed that the relative deviation of manual interpretation was less than 3.8%.
metadata.instructions:
The name of the data file is 2001TPG.
This data is in raster tiff format, witch can be opened in GIS software such as ArcMap.

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Glacier changes on the Tibetan Plateau derived from Landsat imagery: mid-1970s-2000-2013
literatureList.referenceEn: Ye, Q.H., Zong, J.B., Tian, L.D., Cogley, J.G., Song, C.Q., & Guo, W.Q. (2017). Glacier changes on the Tibetan Plateau derived from Landsat imagery: mid-1970s-2000-2013. Journal of Glaciology, 63(238), 273-287. doi:10.1017/jog.2016.137

background: Nearly all mountain glaciers have been melting rapidly in recent decades (Gardner and others, 2013; Zemp and others, 2015) and this has been documented, especially in High Mountain Asia (HMA hereafter), in surveys of the whole (Li and others, 2008; Cogley, 2016) or large parts (Bolch and others, 2012; Yao and others, 2012) of the region as well as in basin-scale and single-glacier studies (Fujita and Nuimura, 2011; Wang and others, 2013; Yang and others, 2013). As reported in these earlier studies, most HMA glaciers showed obvious shrinkage (area loss) and thinning (implying mass loss) except in the west, for example in the Karakoram (Gardelle and others, 2012) and western Kunlun (Neckel and others, 2014; Kääb and others, 2015; Ke and others, 2015). However, due to strong spatiotemporal differences of climate variability and topographic effects, the magnitudes of glacier shrinkage have varied in space and time. The TP, defined by outlines from Zhang and others (2014), can be divided into two categories of hydrological unit, the outlines and basin codes of which we take from Shi and others (2008). Generally, meltwater from glaciers in IB flows into inland depressions, while those in EC flow into the ocean and so contribute more directly to sea-level rise. Climatically, the Indian monsoon dominates in the southeastern TP in summer (e.g. in 5O, 5N, 5L), with some effects from the East Asian monsoon in the east (e.g. in 5Y4, 5J, 5K). The westerlies are dominant in winter, especially in the western TP (e.g. 5Y6, 5Z4, 5Z3). Regions in the interior TP, such as 5Z1, 5Z2, 5Z5, 5Z6 and 5Y5 are less influenced both by the summer monsoon and the westerlies (Yao and others, 2012).
research objective: In this study, we present debris-free glacier area changes and their spatial heterogeneity at the plateau scale from the 1970s to 2013 based on three mosaic Landsat images, i.e. in the 1970s (TPG1970s), TPG2001 and TPG2013. Another purpose of the study is to enrich the available collection of glacier inventories in HMA, by presenting a detailed comparison of TPG datasets with previous glacier inventories.
challenges: We were unable to remove debris-covered areas from the GAMDAM inventory (GGI) (Nuimura and others, 2015), which includes debris cover but does not distinguish it from debris-free ice. Obviously snow and clouds could have affected glacier delineation, especially in southeastern Tibet where cloudy days are rather frequent in every season. Nor is it likely that the area differences are due to different treatment of debris cover, which is omitted in TGP2001 and included in GAMDAM.
methods: Glacier outlines (TPG1976, TPG2001 and TPG2013) were digitized manually with guidance from the SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. To achieve complete multi-temporal coverage in a reasonable time, only debris-free ice was delineated. Time series of Landsat scenes were processed with Standard Terrain Correction (Level 1T), which provided systematic radiometric and geometric accuracy by incorporating ground control points while employing SRTM DEM for topographic accuracy. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage were selected for the delineation of glaciers. Glacier outlines were digitized on-screen manually from the three image mosaics, relying on false-colour image composites (MSS: red, green and blue (RGB) represented by bands 321; TM/ETM+: RGB by bands 543, OLI: RGB by bands 654), which allowed us to distinguish ice and snow from cloud. The manual delineation was carried out by three operators over a period of 6 years. The delineated glacier outlines were validated and edited by different operators at least three times by overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps and corresponding satellite images by another two glacier researchers with field survey experience.
dataset: Glacier area on the plateau decreased from 44 366 ± 2827 km2 (1.7% of the study area) in the 1970s to 42 210 ± 1621 km2 in 2001 and 41 137 ± 1616 km2 in 2013.
findings: The comparative analysis of three mosaics shows that glacier area loss across the entire Tibetan Plateau is unequivocal. The glaciers in the M1970-76 subset showed shrinkage at−0.19% a−1 during 1976– 2001 and −0.20% a−1 during 2001– 13. Glaciers in the M1970-88 subset shrank at −0.34% a−1 during 1988 – 2013, and in the M1970-94 subset at −0.42% a−1 during 1994– 2013. The most dramatic glacier shrinkage occurred in the Mekong basin (region 5L) in the southeast, with change rates for M1970s-76 glaciers of −0.43% a−1 during 1976 – 2013 (−0.31% a−1 during 1976– 2001 and −0.73% a−1 during 2001– 13). Glaciers in the western and northern Tibetan Plateau changed at the slowest rates: −0.12% a−1 in 5Y6, −0.14% a−1 in 5Z1, −0.17% a−1 in 5Y5 and −0.17% a−1 in 5Z5 from 1976 to 2013. Overall, glaciers in externally drained catchments showed more dramatic shrinkage than those in the internally drained catchments. This shows a spatial gradient across the plateau of glacier shrinkage rate, decreasing from the southeast to the north and the west.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method for glacier data on the Tibetan Plateau involve manual digitization of glacier outlines?
Is the accuracy of the data collection method verified through comparison with imagery from multiple sources such as Google Earth and DEMs?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary method for glacier data extraction based on manual digitization, automated algorithms, or a combination of both?

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the challenges most pronounced when delineating glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau using remote sensing data?
When did the glacier area on the Tibetan Plateau undergo the most significant shrinkage, according to Landsat imagery analysis?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to delineate glacier outlines on the Tibetan Plateau from satellite imagery?
Example.Answer: One data collection method involved digitizing glacier outlines manually using false-color image composites from Landsat satellite imagery. This process included using Standard Terrain Correction to ensure radiometric and geometric accuracy, and employed SRTM DEM for topographic accuracy. The manual delineation was validated and edited by multiple operators using Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps, and corresponding satellite images.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that illustrates glacier area changes on the Tibetan Plateau over multiple decades?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the one showing glacier area changes from the 1970s to 2013 on the Tibetan Plateau. It indicates that the glacier area decreased from 44,366 ± 2,827 km² in the 1970s to 42,210 ± 1,621 km² in 2001 and further to 41,137 ± 1,616 km² in 2013, illustrating a clear trend of glacier shrinkage over the decades.

Feature Specification.Question: What methodological challenges are involved in delineating glaciers from satellite imagery?
Feature Specification.Answer: inability to remove debris-covered areas, presence of snow and clouds, requires careful validation and editing by multiple operators, difficulties distinguishing between ice, snow, and cloud in false-color composites

Quantification.Question: What is the grid cell resolution used for capturing glacier data on the Tibetan Plateau?
What is the overall data processing error percentage reported for the glacier dataset from 2001?
How many Landsat images were used in the creation of the glacier dataset for the Tibetan Plateau in 2001?

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with delineating debris-covered glaciers in satellite imagery, and how are they addressed in data collection methods?
Definition.Answer: Delineating debris-covered glaciers is challenging because debris can obscure glacier boundaries, making it difficult to distinguish between debris-covered ice and surrounding landscapes. In the dataset collection, this challenge is addressed by excluding debris-covered areas from the glacier outlines, focusing only on debris-free ice, and using high-quality imagery with minimal clouds and snow for accurate delineation.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of removing debris-covered areas affect the accuracy of glacier datasets compared to datasets that only include debris-free ice?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets that focus only on debris-free ice, like those derived from TPG2001, avoid the inaccuracies associated with failing to distinguish debris from ice, a challenge faced by other inventories such as GAMDAM, which includes but does not distinguish debris-covered areas.

Comparison.Question: How do the spatial coverage and temporal scope of glacier datasets using Landsat imagery compare to other remote sensing data sources for studying glacier changes over time?
Comparison.Answer: The glacier datasets based on Landsat imagery provide comprehensive multi-temporal coverage, enabling detailed analysis of changes from the 1970s to 2013. This temporal scope may offer advantages over other remote sensing sources that might lack consistent longitudinal data or the spatial resolution provided by the Landsat series.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of distinguishing debris-covered ice from debris-free ice in glacier datasets, and how might these challenges affect data accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: The inability to remove debris-covered areas from certain glacier inventories suggests challenges in accurately delineating glacier boundaries, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover. This can affect the accuracy of glacier area measurements and lead to discrepancies between different datasets.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of multiple data sources and methods contribute to the accuracy and reliability of glacier data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of multiple data sources, such as Landsat imagery, SRTM DEM, and Google Earth, combined with methods like manual delineation and expert validation, can enhance the precision of glacier boundary extraction by mitigating the impact of factors like seasonal snow cover and mountain shadows.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the impact of climate variability and topographic effects on the spatial heterogeneity of glacier changes across the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The variations in glacier shrinkage rates across different regions of the Tibetan Plateau suggest that climate variability and topographic effects play significant roles in influencing glacier dynamics, resulting in spatially heterogeneous patterns of glacier area loss.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in accurately removing debris-covered areas when digitizing glacier outlines from satellite imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise because certain inventories, like GAMDAM, include debris cover but do not distinguish it from debris-free ice, complicating delineation. Additionally, frequent cloud cover and snow, particularly in southeastern Tibet, can obscure glacier features, adding to the difficulty.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the spatial gradient of glacier shrinkage rates observed across the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial gradient is influenced by climatic variations, with externally drained catchments experiencing more dramatic shrinkage than internally drained ones. The regional climate, dominated by the Indian and East Asian monsoons in the southeast and westerlies in the west, affects glacier melting rates, resulting in a gradient from southeast to north and west.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using multi-source data and human expertise in glacier data extraction on the accuracy of glacier delineation in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of multi-source data and human expertise can enhance the accuracy of glacier delineation, as it allows for the integration of various data types and expert knowledge, resulting in more precise glacier vector data. Specifically, it helps in eliminating non-glacial features such as mountain shadows and seasonal snow, and ensures that glacier boundaries are digitized with high precision, within half a pixel (15m).

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of creating a dataset using Landsat imagery for studying glacier changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to present debris-free glacier area changes and their spatial heterogeneity at the plateau scale from the 1970s to 2013, and to enrich the available collection of glacier inventories in High Mountain Asia by providing a detailed comparison with previous inventories.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to differentiate between debris-covered and debris-free ice in datasets related to glacier studies in High Mountain Asia?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Differentiating between debris-covered and debris-free ice is important because it helps in accurately delineating glacier outlines, which is crucial for understanding glacier shrinkage and changes. Debris cover can obscure the true extent of glaciers, leading to inaccuracies in glacier inventories.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to manually digitize glacier outlines using Landsat imagery and ensure their accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Glacier outlines are digitized manually using guidance from SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. The manual delineation is carried out by three operators over a period of six years. Glacier outlines are validated and edited by different operators at least three times by overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps, and corresponding satellite images, ensuring accuracy and consistency.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can multi-temporal Landsat scenes be processed to minimize cloud and snow coverage for glacier delineation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Time series of Landsat scenes are processed with Standard Terrain Correction (Level 1T) to provide systematic radiometric and geometric accuracy. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage are selected for the delineation of glaciers, utilizing false-color image composites to distinguish ice and snow from cloud.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the accurate delineation of glacier boundaries in remote sensing datasets used for studying the Tibetan Plateau glaciers?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate delineation of glacier boundaries is enabled by the manual digitization of glacier outlines using satellite imagery, such as Landsat scenes, which are processed with Standard Terrain Correction for radiometric and geometric accuracy. This process involves the use of false-colour image composites and guidance from SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery, with validation and editing by multiple operators with field survey experience.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies facilitate the exclusion of debris-covered areas in glacier inventories for high mountain regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The exclusion of debris-covered areas in glacier inventories is facilitated by the manual delineation of debris-free ice using high-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage, as well as careful validation using different imagery sources. However, challenges remain in removing debris-covered areas from certain inventories, as manual delineation focuses primarily on debris-free ice.

Expectation.Question: Why might debris-covered glaciers be challenging to accurately delineate in remote sensing datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Debris-covered areas can be difficult to remove from inventories as they are often indistinguishable from debris-free ice in certain datasets, and snow or clouds can further affect glacier delineation, especially in regions with frequent cloudy conditions.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the varying rates of glacier shrinkage across different regions in the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The spatial heterogeneity of glacier shrinkage rates could be influenced by climate variability, topographic effects, and the presence of different hydrological units that affect how meltwater contributes to sea-level rise or local depressions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the manual digitization of glacier outlines be preferred over automated methods in certain glacial studies?
Expectation.Answer: Manual digitization allows for greater accuracy in delineating debris-free ice, using high-quality imagery and expert validation processes, which might not be possible with automated methods that may struggle with debris cover or cloud and snow interference.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using multiple data sources and manual interpretation for glacier data extraction on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multiple data sources such as Landsat imagery, SRTM DEM, and Google Earth, combined with manual interpretation, is generally considered effective for glacier data extraction. The integration of these varied data sources helps in accounting for factors like mountain shadows and seasonal snow, enhancing the accuracy of the glacier outlines. However, the process requires significant human expertise and labor, which can be a limitation in terms of efficiency and scalability.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise from excluding debris-covered areas in glacier delineation, and how could these affect the understanding of glacier changes?
Judgmental.Answer: Excluding debris-covered areas can lead to underestimation of glacier extent and may not fully capture the dynamics of glacier changes. This exclusion could affect the understanding of glacier mass balance and hydrological contributions, as debris-covered glaciers may have different melting patterns. Accurately delineating these areas remains challenging due to the difficulty in distinguishing debris-covered ice from surrounding terrain using remote sensing imagery alone.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what potential improvements or innovations could enhance the accuracy and efficiency of glacier inventory updates in High Mountain Asia?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential improvements could include the utilization of higher-resolution satellite imagery and the application of machine learning techniques for automated delineation of glacier outlines. Combining multi-temporal datasets with advanced algorithms could help overcome challenges of cloud cover and seasonal variations. Additionally, integrating in-situ data and leveraging crowd-sourced validations could further refine the accuracy and reliability of glacier inventories.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset on glacier changes across the Tibetan Plateau can achieve high precision when dealing with snow and cloud cover.
Assertion.Answer: The glacier outlines were digitized manually with guidance from SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery to ensure accuracy. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage were selected for delineation. The manual delineation was validated and edited by different operators multiple times to enhance precision.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how multiple operators working over several years can ensure consistent data quality in glacier mapping.
Assertion.Answer: The delineated glacier outlines were validated and edited by different operators at least three times by overlaying them onto imagery, DEMs, and maps, ensuring consistent data quality. This collaborative approach, combined with expert review, contributes to maintaining accuracy and reliability in the data.
